title: Mourning Gecko Feeding Guide: Complete Nutrition Protocol
description: Comprehensive feeding guide for mourning geckos covering crested gecko diet (CGD), insect variety, supplementation, feeding schedules, and nutrition for breeding colonies.
excerpt: Comprehensive feeding guide for mourning geckos covering crested gecko diet (CGD), insect variety, supplementation, feeding schedules, and nutrition for breeding colonies.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Complete Nutritional Guide for Mourning Geckos
content.content: Mourning geckos are omnivores that eat fruit and insects in the wild. In captivity, their diet is simplified using commercial crested gecko diet (CGD) as the staple food, supplemented with live insects 1-2x weekly. This combination provides complete nutrition and enrichment. Because all mourning geckos are female and reproduce continuously via parthenogenesis, proper nutrition - especially calcium - is critical for egg production and hatchling health.

Commercial crested gecko diet powder is the cornerstone of mourning gecko nutrition. These meal replacement powders are specifically formulated with complete nutrition including protein, vitamins, minerals, and calcium. Mix powder with water to create a smoothie-like consistency.

content.text: Recommended CGD Brands:

rows: Most popular, high quality, insects optional
High protein, good for breeding colonies

content.content: Mixing Instructions: Use 2 parts powder to 1 part water (by weight). Example: 2 teaspoons powder + 1 teaspoon water. Stir vigorously until smooth and creamy. Consistency should be like applesauce or yogurt - not runny. Mix fresh for each feeding; do not prepare in bulk and store.
CGD is nutritionally complete - you can raise mourning geckos on CGD alone. However, adding insects 1-2x weekly provides enrichment, variety, and mental stimulation through hunting behaviors.
Mourning geckos should have constant access to CGD, with food replaced every 24-48 hours to prevent spoilage. Insects are offered weekly as supplemental enrichment.

content.text: Weekly Feeding Protocol:

content.content: Simplified Schedule: Provide CGD continuously (replace every 24-48 hours). Offer calcium-dusted insects 1-2x per week. Skip one CGD feeding per week to simulate natural fasting (optional but healthy).
NEVER leave CGD longer than 48 hours - it will mold and cause illness. In hot/humid conditions, replace after 24 hours. Discard any CGD that develops mold, strange odor, or separated liquid.
Live insects provide enrichment and dietary variety. Mourning geckos are small (4 inches), so insect size is critical - nothing larger than the width between their eyes.

content.text: Appropriate Feeder Insects:

rows: BEST for tiny geckos, easy hunting

content.content: Sizing Rule: Insects should be NO WIDER than the space between the gecko's eyes. For mourning geckos, this means TINY insects - most standard "small" crickets are too large. Fruit flies and pinhead crickets are ideal.
Oversized insects can cause impaction or choking. When in doubt, go smaller! Fruit flies are always safe and provide excellent hunting enrichment.
While CGD is complete nutrition, insects are nutritionally poor and must be dusted with calcium powder before feeding. This balances their poor calcium-to-phosphorus ratio.

content.text: Supplement Protocol:

rows: Arcadia CalciumPro Mg, MinerAll Outdoor, Repashy SuperCal NoD

content.content: Dusting Technique: Place insects in small cup or bag, add pinch of calcium powder, shake gently to coat. Feed insects immediately while powder is fresh. For fruit flies, use dusting cup to lightly coat before pouring into enclosure.

Because CGD provides complete vitamins and minerals, you ONLY need to dust insects with plain calcium (no D3). Do not use multivitamins - CGD already provides these, and over-supplementation can cause toxicity.
Proper food presentation ensures all geckos have access and reduces competition. Multiple feeding stations are essential for colonies.

content.text: Feeding Station Setup:

rows: Elevated (prevents substrate contamination), multiple stations possible
Reusable, easy to clean, prevents food waste

content.content: Colony Feeding Tips: For groups of 4+ geckos, provide at least 2-3 feeding stations at different heights. This prevents dominant geckos from monopolizing food. Rotate station locations weekly to reduce territorial behavior.
All mourning geckos are female and can lay eggs every 4-6 weeks. Egg production demands extra calcium and protein. Breeding colonies need enhanced nutrition.

content.text: Enhanced Nutrition for Egg-Layers:

rows: Increase to 2-3x weekly during laying season
Ensure every insect feeding is dusted
ESSENTIAL - aids calcium absorption for egg development

content.content: Signs of nutritional deficiency in breeding females: soft/rubbery eggs, egg binding, lethargy, loss of appetite. Increase calcium dusting frequency, ensure UVB is functioning, and consult a vet if egg binding suspected.
Mourning geckos do NOT drink from water dishes - they are droplet drinkers who lick water from leaves after misting. CGD also provides dietary moisture.

content.text: Hydration Sources:

content.content: NEVER provide a water dish - mourning geckos are too small and can drown in even shallow water. All hydration comes from misting and dietary moisture in CGD.
Track feeding patterns to ensure all geckos are eating and to adjust quantities as the colony grows.

content.text: Consumption Indicators:

rows: Colony is eating well, may need more food
Increase CGD amount or add extra feeding station
Too much food, not hungry, or illness
Reduce portion size, monitor geckos for health issues
Add more feeding stations at different heights
Not hungry or insects too large
Reduce CGD slightly or ensure insects are tiny
Enclosure too humid or CGD expired
Replace CGD more frequently (24h max), check humidity

content.content: Some foods marketed for geckos are inappropriate or dangerous for mourning geckos.

content.text: Unsafe or Poor-Quality Foods:

rows: Nutritionally inadequate, lacks calcium, high sugar
Empty calories, high sugar, no protein or calcium
Choking/impaction risk, too large for tiny geckos
Far too large, aggressive, can bite geckos
Extremely high fat, addictive, nutritionally poor
Sticky, high sugar, no nutritional value

content.content: Do NOT attempt to create homemade CGD substitutes using baby food, fruit puree, or other ingredients. Commercial CGD is specifically formulated with precise calcium, vitamin, and protein ratios that cannot be replicated at home.
Regular body condition checks ensure your feeding regimen is appropriate. Mourning geckos should have plump tails and rounded bodies.

content.text: Body Condition Scoring:

rows: Visible ribs, thin tail base, prominent hip bones
Increase CGD amount, add 3rd insect feeding weekly, check for bullying
Tail base thick, body rounded, ribs not visible, active
Excessive tail fat, swollen body, reduced activity
Reduce CGD portions slightly, maintain insects, increase enclosure enrichment

content.content: Breeding females may appear plumper due to egg development - this is normal. However, if a gecko appears bloated with no egg laying, consult a vet for potential egg binding or other issues.

content.text: Mistakes to Avoid:

rows: Only one feeding station for colony
Use only fruit flies, pinheads, or baby insects
Metabolic bone disease, poor egg quality
Dust ALL insects with plain calcium powder
Remove dish - mist for hydration instead
Using baby food instead of CGD
Check feeding stations daily, observe all geckos
